<p><strong>Would you be able to buy a car</strong> or a house without taking out a loan? Most of us wouldn’t. What about paying for emergency healthcare without insurance? Same story. For those who don’t have access to financial services, it’s almost impossible to save enough to pay the bills, much less build the kind of wealth that can be passed on to the next generation.</p>
<!-- -->
<p>Financial inclusion is a major issue around the world. <a href="https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2022/07/21/covid-19-boosted-the-adoption-of-digital-financial-services#:~:text=Globally%2C%20some%201.4%20billion%20adults,go%2C%20much%20more%20is%20needed">Nearly a billion and a half people</a> living in emerging economies don’t have access to formal savings and credit. They pay for everything in cash, have no secure way to save and invest their money, and rely on informal lenders and personal networks for credit. And just because the United States is one of the world’s wealthiest countries doesn’t mean the situation is any better there. A recent McKinsey survey of 25,000 Americans found that only half would be able to <a href="/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/future-of-america/financial-inclusion-and-sustainable-inclusive-growth-in-action">cover expenses for more than two months</a> if they lost their job. What’s more, millions of Americans are underbanked—that means you have a bank account, but to manage your finances, you still rely on things such as money orders, check-cashing services, and payday loans, which are relatively expensive to use compared with credit cards or traditional loans.</p>
<p>But, while the overall global wealth and income gap has narrowed since the 1980s, <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/inequality-a-persisting-challenge-and-its-implications">inequality has actually increased</a> within advanced economies. The difference between financial inclusion and exclusion in the United States frequently comes down to race (although rural, immigrant, LGBTQ+, and less-educated communities also tend to be underbanked). Black communities, in particular, have been the targets of <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities">exclusionary financial practices</a> and strategies for generations, including limited access to federal mortgage lending, imposed geographic barriers such as redlining, and the absence of physical bank branches in Black-majority communities. As of 2016, the average Black American family had only about one-tenth the wealth of the average White American family. This is a symptom of the racial wealth gap but also a cause: without access to financial services, it’s difficult to turn income into wealth. </p>
<p>That’s because financial inclusion is more than just the ability to open a bank account, make a payment, or get a loan. It’s also a means to an end. Financial inclusion can bridge the divide between economic opportunity and economic achievement. Our current moment presents a meaningful opportunity to counteract centuries of marginalization—and create opportunities for overall economic growth.</p>
<p>Read on to learn more about what financial inclusion means and why it matters.</p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a>. </em></p>
<h2>How can mobile providers help increase financial inclusion globally?</h2>
<p>There’s a huge opportunity for mobile providers (particularly in emerging markets) to improve financial inclusion for the billions of unbanked people, as well as to create immense value by tapping into a <a href="/featured-insights/employment-and-growth/how-digital-finance-could-boost-growth-in-emerging-economies">huge and largely untouched market</a>. In 2018, McKinsey projected that digital finance had the potential to reach more than 1.6 billion new retail customers in emerging economies, and to increase the volume of loans extended to individuals and businesses <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/mobile-money-in-emerging-markets-the-business-case-for-financial-inclusion">by $2.1 trillion</a>. At the time, McKinsey projected that the providers of these products stood to increase their balance sheets by up to a total of $4.2 trillion. While this was several years ago, a significant opportunity remains: according to the <a href="https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/globalfindex#sec2">World Bank’s 2021 Global Findex report</a>, up to 38 percent of adults in developing countries remain unbanked.</p>
<p>But an untapped market of this size is a landscape of unknowns. To help understand how digital-payments providers can capture opportunities and improve financial inclusion, in 2018 McKinsey analyzed proprietary and publicly available data from East Africa, West Africa, and Southeast Asia. The findings were clear: while there was great opportunity, providers needed to invest significantly, for the long term, in new kinds of partnerships. Ultimately, we determined, profitability relied on scale—but to achieve the scale necessary to break even, we estimated that providers would have needed to spend enough to see <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/mobile-money-in-emerging-markets-the-business-case-for-financial-inclusion">$2 billion or even $3 billion in annual transaction value</a>. Such scale would have required significant and long-term IT spending, as well as personnel and real estate costs. </p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <em><a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a></em>. </em></p>
<h2>What is open financial data and how can it improve global financial inclusion?</h2>
<!-- -->
<p>Open financial data is a critical enabler of financial inclusion. The phrase “open financial data” refers to the ability to share financial data through a digital ecosystem in a way that requires limited effort or manual intervention. A 2021 McKinsey Global Institute analysis found that broad adoption of open-data systems could confer up to a <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-data-unbound-the-value-of-open-data-for-individuals-and-institutions">1.5 percent gain in GDP</a> by 2030 in the United Kingdom, European Union, and the United States, and as much as 5 percent in India. </p>
<p>Open financial data can create economic value by benefiting financial institutions, individuals, and small and midsize enterprise customers. For consumers, benefits include the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Increased access to financial services.</em> Open data sharing can enable customers to buy and use financial services they might not be able to otherwise access. For example, limited data in some markets might disqualify customers from accessing loans. Open data can help assess the creditworthiness of potential borrowers by sourcing rent, phone, and utility bill payment history.</li>
    <li><em>Greater user convenience. </em>Data sharing can save time for customers in their interactions with financial-service providers. For instance, open access to data on available mortgage products can allow customers to apply for loans without needing to go through mortgage brokers.</li>
    <li><em>Improved product options. </em>An open-data system could make it easier to switch accounts from one institution for another, helping customers get the best yield.</li>
</ul>
<p>Open-data initiatives are increasingly common globally. These include the UK’s Open Banking Implementation Entity, the EU’s second Payment Services Directive, Australia’s new consumer protection laws, Brazil’s drafting of open-data guidelines, and Nigeria’s new Open Technology Foundation (Open Banking Nigeria). </p>

<h2>What role can financial institutions play in closing the US racial wealth gap?</h2>
<p>The racial gap in the United States has persisted for decades. The median Black family has about <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-role-of-financial-services-in-improving-racial-equity-in-the-us">13 percent of the wealth</a> of the median White family, and nearly half of Black households are underbanked. Black Americans are also more likely to be served subprime financial products, such as loans with higher interest rates that increase over time, which can be harder to pay off than regular loans.</p>
<p>The financial-services sector has a critical role to play in addressing these disparities. In 2022, McKinsey convened leaders across the ecosystem to discuss how the industry can improve its service to Black communities. </p>
<p><em>Learn more about McKinsey’s <em><a href="/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients">Financial Services Practice</a></em>. </em></p>
<h2>How would greater financial inclusion benefit the US economy?</h2>
<p>Increased inclusion of Black Americans in the financial system would benefit the entire economy: Black families with better access to financial services would have more opportunity to reinvest and grow their wealth, and thereby support increased economic activity. The McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility estimates that addressing the racial wealth gap could lead to <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-role-of-financial-services-in-improving-racial-equity-in-the-us">an additional 5 percent of GDP growth</a> in the United States. </p>
<p>Leaving aside the moral imperative for financial inclusion, greater inclusion of Black Americans in the financial system would create opportunities for financial-services companies. If Black Americans had the same access to financial products of White Americans, financial institutions could realize up to <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities">approximately $2 billion</a> in incremental, additional revenue. Further, if Black Americans and White Americans achieve full wealth parity, financial-services companies could realize up to $60 billion in additional revenue from Black customers every year. </p>
<h2>What are five key aspects of financial inclusion for Black Americans?</h2>
<p>In the United States, nearly half of Black households are unbanked or underbanked. Here are five key aspects that denote full financial inclusion, along with why achieving them is a struggle for many Black Americans:</p>
<ol>
    <li>
    <p><em>Be able to make everyday transactions through a safe and affordable transaction account.</em> Even seemingly mundane financial actions, such as depositing or accessing monthly paychecks, are significantly more costly for the average Black American family. Many Black Americans rely on check-cashing services due to a <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities">lack of bank storefronts</a> in majority Black or Brown neighborhoods. These typically charge a fee of about 3 percent. What’s more, Black American families pay on average $40 per month in bank fees and penalties—for using ATMs or falling under the minimum-required balance.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><em>Have access to credit.</em> Lack of access to credit has far-reaching consequences for many Black Americans. For example, car ownership is essential for many Americans to hold down a job. But owning a car is more expensive for Black Americans. Research shows that Black and Brown car shoppers who are more qualified than their White counterparts are <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities">62.5 percent more likely</a> to be offered a costlier pricing option. And Black Americans are twice as likely to be denied credit compared with White Americans.</p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><em>Hold insurance against risk.</em> There are huge disparities in the types of insurance products available to Black and White Americans. Whereas 73 percent of White families have private health insurance, <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities">only 57 percent</a> of Black families can say the same. </p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><em>Be able to save for big goals or rainy days.</em> A cushion of readily available liquid assets lets families pay for college, save for retirement, or deal with unexpected financial events. Black families are less likely to have such a cushion: the average White family has 31 days of liquid savings on hand, whereas the average Black family has <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities">only five</a>. </p>
    </li>
    <li>
    <p><em>Ultimately accumulate long-term wealth.</em> Buying a home is typically a key step in building family wealth. Homes appreciate in value over time, add to net worth, and become a key asset to pass down to future generations. But for Black Americans, homeownership is a much harder goal to achieve. Black Americans are denied loans at more than double the rate as White Americans (<a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities">28 versus 11 percent</a>). And they are offered higher-cost loans compared with White borrowers with similar credit scores. </p>
    </li>
</ol>
<p>These different financial experiences have compounding effects. Just 8 percent of Black families leave inheritances to their children, compared with 26 percent of White families.</p>

type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"What is financial inclusion","displayName":"What is financial inclusion","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"30d0bed4-703b-4294-9dbb-6c8791b1af28","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"What is financial inclusion?"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":""},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Financial inclusion is when everyone can access financial services that can help them build wealth, including savings, credit, loans, equity, and insurance."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"What is financial inclusion? How can it benefit the US economy? Discover answers to these questions—and more—in our latest McKinsey Explainer."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2023-08-07T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[Image 1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWould you be able to buy a car\u003c/strong\u003e or a house without taking out a loan? Most of us wouldn\u0026rsquo;t. What about paying for emergency healthcare without insurance? Same story. For those who don\u0026rsquo;t have access to financial services, it\u0026rsquo;s almost impossible to save enough to pay the bills, much less build the kind of wealth that can be passed on to the next generation.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eFinancial inclusion is a major issue around the world. \u003ca href=\"https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2022/07/21/covid-19-boosted-the-adoption-of-digital-financial-services#:~:text=Globally%2C%20some%201.4%20billion%20adults,go%2C%20much%20more%20is%20needed\"\u003eNearly a billion and a half people\u003c/a\u003e living in emerging economies don\u0026rsquo;t have access to formal savings and credit. They pay for everything in cash, have no secure way to save and invest their money, and rely on informal lenders and personal networks for credit. And just because the United States is one of the world\u0026rsquo;s wealthiest countries doesn\u0026rsquo;t mean the situation is any better there. A recent McKinsey survey of 25,000 Americans found that only half would be able to \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/future-of-america/financial-inclusion-and-sustainable-inclusive-growth-in-action\"\u003ecover expenses for more than two months\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;if they lost their job. What\u0026rsquo;s more, millions of Americans are underbanked\u0026mdash;that means you have a bank account, but to manage your finances, you still rely on things such as money orders, check-cashing services, and payday loans, which are relatively expensive to use compared with credit cards or traditional loans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut, while the overall global wealth and income gap has narrowed since the 1980s, \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/inequality-a-persisting-challenge-and-its-implications\"\u003einequality has actually increased\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;within advanced economies. The difference between financial inclusion and exclusion in the United States frequently comes down to race (although rural, immigrant, LGBTQ+, and less-educated communities also tend to be underbanked). Black communities, in particular, have been the targets of \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities\"\u003eexclusionary financial practices\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and strategies for generations, including limited access to federal mortgage lending, imposed geographic barriers such as redlining, and the absence of physical bank branches in Black-majority communities. As of 2016, the average Black American family had only about one-tenth the wealth of the average White American family. This is a symptom of the racial wealth gap but also a cause: without access to financial services, it\u0026rsquo;s difficult to turn income into wealth. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat\u0026rsquo;s because financial inclusion is more than just the ability to open a bank account, make a payment, or get a loan. It\u0026rsquo;s also a means to an end. Financial inclusion can bridge the divide between economic opportunity and economic achievement. Our current moment presents a meaningful opportunity to counteract centuries of marginalization\u0026mdash;and create opportunities for overall economic growth.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eRead on to learn more about what financial inclusion means and why it matters.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow can mobile providers help increase financial inclusion globally?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere\u0026rsquo;s a huge opportunity for mobile providers (particularly in emerging markets) to improve financial inclusion for the billions of unbanked people, as well as to create immense value by tapping into a \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/employment-and-growth/how-digital-finance-could-boost-growth-in-emerging-economies\"\u003ehuge and largely untouched market\u003c/a\u003e. In 2018, McKinsey projected that digital finance had the potential to reach more than 1.6 billion new retail customers in emerging economies, and to increase the volume of loans extended to individuals and businesses \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/mobile-money-in-emerging-markets-the-business-case-for-financial-inclusion\"\u003eby $2.1 trillion\u003c/a\u003e. At the time, McKinsey projected that the providers of these products stood to increase their balance sheets by up to a total of $4.2 trillion. While this was several years ago, a significant opportunity remains: according to the \u003ca href=\"https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/globalfindex#sec2\"\u003eWorld Bank\u0026rsquo;s 2021 Global Findex report\u003c/a\u003e, up to 38 percent of adults in developing countries remain unbanked.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut an untapped market of this size is a landscape of unknowns. To help understand how digital-payments providers can capture opportunities and improve financial inclusion, in 2018 McKinsey analyzed proprietary and publicly available data from East Africa, West Africa, and Southeast Asia. The findings were clear: while there was great opportunity, providers needed to invest significantly, for the long term, in new kinds of partnerships. Ultimately, we determined, profitability relied on scale\u0026mdash;but to achieve the scale necessary to break even, we estimated that providers would have needed to spend enough to see \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/mobile-money-in-emerging-markets-the-business-case-for-financial-inclusion\"\u003e$2 billion or even $3 billion in annual transaction value\u003c/a\u003e. Such scale would have required significant and long-term IT spending, as well as personnel and real estate costs. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat is open financial data and how can it improve global financial inclusion?\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Video 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eOpen financial data is a critical enabler of financial inclusion. The phrase \u0026ldquo;open financial data\u0026rdquo; refers to the ability to share financial data through a digital ecosystem in a way that requires limited effort or manual intervention. A 2021 McKinsey Global Institute analysis found that broad adoption of open-data systems could confer up to a \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/financial-data-unbound-the-value-of-open-data-for-individuals-and-institutions\"\u003e1.5 percent gain in GDP\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;by 2030 in the United Kingdom, European Union, and the United States, and as much as 5 percent in India. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOpen financial data can create economic value by benefiting financial institutions, individuals, and small and midsize enterprise customers. For consumers, benefits include the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIncreased access to financial services.\u003c/em\u003e Open data sharing can enable customers to buy and use financial services they might not be able to otherwise access. For example, limited data in some markets might disqualify customers from accessing loans. Open data can help assess the creditworthiness of potential borrowers by sourcing rent, phone, and utility bill payment history.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGreater user convenience. \u003c/em\u003eData sharing can save time for customers in their interactions with financial-service providers. For instance, open access to data on available mortgage products can allow customers to apply for loans without needing to go through mortgage brokers.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImproved product options. \u003c/em\u003eAn open-data system could make it easier to switch accounts from one institution for another, helping customers get the best yield.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOpen-data initiatives are increasingly common globally. These include the UK\u0026rsquo;s Open Banking\u0026nbsp;Implementation Entity, the EU\u0026rsquo;s second Payment Services Directive, Australia\u0026rsquo;s new consumer protection laws, Brazil\u0026rsquo;s drafting of open-data guidelines, and Nigeria\u0026rsquo;s new Open Technology Foundation (Open Banking Nigeria). \u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1Up mckinseyexplainers]]\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat role can financial institutions play in closing the US racial wealth gap?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe racial gap in the United States has persisted for decades. The median Black family has about \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-role-of-financial-services-in-improving-racial-equity-in-the-us\"\u003e13 percent of the wealth\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of the median White family, and nearly half of Black households are underbanked. Black Americans are also more likely to be served subprime financial products, such as loans with higher interest rates that increase over time, which can be harder to pay off than regular loans.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe financial-services sector has a critical role to play in addressing these disparities. In 2022, McKinsey convened leaders across the ecosystem to discuss how the industry can improve its service to Black communities. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/how-we-help-clients\"\u003eFinancial Services Practice\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e. \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHow would greater financial inclusion benefit the US economy?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIncreased inclusion of Black Americans in the financial system would benefit the entire economy: Black families with better access to financial services would have more opportunity to reinvest and grow their wealth, and thereby support increased economic activity. The McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility estimates that addressing the racial wealth gap could lead to \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-role-of-financial-services-in-improving-racial-equity-in-the-us\"\u003ean additional 5 percent of GDP growth\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in the United States. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLeaving aside the moral imperative for financial inclusion, greater inclusion of Black Americans in the financial system would create opportunities for financial-services companies. If Black Americans had the same access to financial products of White Americans, financial institutions could realize up to \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities\"\u003eapproximately $2 billion\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in incremental, additional revenue. Further, if Black Americans and White Americans achieve full wealth parity, financial-services companies could realize up to $60 billion in additional revenue from Black customers every year. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWhat are five key aspects of financial inclusion for Black Americans?\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, nearly half of Black households are unbanked or underbanked. Here are five key aspects that denote full financial inclusion, along with why achieving them is a struggle for many Black Americans:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBe able to make everyday transactions through a safe and affordable transaction account.\u003c/em\u003e Even seemingly mundane financial actions, such as depositing or accessing monthly paychecks, are significantly more costly for the average Black American family. Many Black Americans rely on check-cashing services due to a \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities\"\u003elack of bank storefronts\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in majority Black or Brown neighborhoods. These typically charge a fee of about 3 percent. What\u0026rsquo;s more, Black American families pay on average $40 per month in bank fees and penalties\u0026mdash;for using ATMs or falling under the minimum-required balance.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eHave access to credit.\u003c/em\u003e Lack of access to credit has far-reaching consequences for many Black Americans. For example, car ownership is essential for many Americans to hold down a job. But owning a car is more expensive for Black Americans. Research shows that Black and Brown car shoppers who are more qualified than their White counterparts are \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities\"\u003e62.5 percent more likely\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to be offered a costlier pricing option. And Black Americans are twice as likely\u0026nbsp;to be denied credit compared with White Americans.\u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eHold insurance against risk.\u003c/em\u003e There are huge disparities in the types of insurance products available to Black and White Americans. Whereas 73 percent of White families have private health insurance, \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities\"\u003eonly 57 percent\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of Black families can say the same. \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBe able to save for big goals or rainy days.\u003c/em\u003e A cushion of readily available liquid assets lets families pay for college, save for retirement, or deal with unexpected financial events. Black families are less likely to have such a cushion: the average White family has 31 days of liquid savings on hand, whereas the average Black family has \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities\"\u003eonly five\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\n    \u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eUltimately accumulate long-term wealth.\u003c/em\u003e Buying a home is typically a key step in building family wealth. Homes appreciate in value over time, add to net worth, and become a key asset to pass down to future generations. But for Black Americans, homeownership is a much harder goal to achieve. Black Americans are denied loans at more than double the rate as White Americans (\u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-case-for-accelerating-financial-inclusion-in-black-communities\"\u003e28 versus 11 percent\u003c/a\u003e). And they are offered higher-cost loans compared with White borrowers with similar credit scores. \u003c/p\u003e\n    \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese different financial experiences have compounding effects. Just 8 percent of Black families leave inheritances to their children, compared with 26 percent of White families.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eLearn more about McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/how-we-help-clients\"\u003ePublic Sector Practice\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;and check out \u003ca href=\"https://www.mckinsey.com/careers/search-jobs?query=decision%20making\"\u003ejob opportunities related to financial inclusion\u003c/a\u003e if you\u0026rsquo;re interested in working at McKinsey.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePop quiz\u003c/h2\u003e\n[[Quiz 13]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eArticles referenced:\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n
